Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2010 03:24PM Lisa73 wrote: That is fantastic!  I would LOVE a good night's sleep - I used to sleep for 8 hours straight.  Now I can't sleep for more than 2 hours at a time and I am lucky if I sleep for 6-7 hours in total.  Nothing helps; I just can't seem to get my mind to stop thinking!  Wishing you many more med-free, peaceful slumbers. Lisa
Posts.Title: I finally slept 8 hours straight!!! tooyoungtohavebc heatherpalmerton

Posts.Content: May 19, 2010 08:38AM Lisa73 wrote: Paula:  Thank you for your reply.  Sorry to hear you have had to have so many chemos in the past year.  Right now I am feeling pretty awful and looking forward to chemo tomorrow - bet that is not a phrase commonly used except in our club :)  Hoping that the dosage will keep the naseau to a minimum, but if not, I will deal with it.  Best wishes to you. Lisa
Posts.Title: Progression :( Anyone been on Doxorubicin? Lisa73 AliceJean

Posts.Content: Lisa73 wrote: Hi LadIes: The last time I posted a question was about 3 weeks ago and it was regarding a pathological fracture in my hip that was causing me difficulty walking.  Long story short, the orthopedic surgeon did not recommend surgery at this point, so I am taking Baclofen (a muscle relaxant) and doing physio to help stretch out the muscles in my leg.  Over the past 2 weeks (since I started taking the Baclofen) my appetite has slowly diminished, I am easily winded walking from room to room, and I just generally felt unwell.  I was blaming it on the Baclofen, but I saw my oncologist today and my bloodwork shows a different story.  My platelets are REALLY low, my LDH is up and my liver function is down.  The onc said that all of that, combined with my other syptoms, means disease progression.  She wants me to start a new chemo on Thursday called doxorubicin (once a week for 3 weeks and then one week off).  So I was just wondering it anyone else had used this chemo with any success?  It kind of scares me that you can only use this chemo for a limited time due to its toxic effects.  Have any of you achieved stability with this drug?? As a bit of background, I did 12 months of Taxotere (which held me stable), followed by 2 months of Tamoxifen up to this point.  So now I am on to the next chemo and just wondering what to expect.  I had very little naseau with the Taxotere, and not sure what to expect from this one.  Any advice would be greatly appreciated.  Thanks, Lisa Dx 2/24/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Progression :( Anyone been on Doxorubicin? Lisa73 AliceJean

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2010 02:34PM Lisa73 wrote: I have had my port for nearly a year (Apr. 03/09).  When I started chemo last year, it took them three tries to find a vein that would take the IV - OUCH!  Then I ended up in the hospital for a week with an infection along the vein that they used.  I had my port put in on a Friday and used it for chemo #2 on the following Monday.  At first it was a bit strange to have something under your skins and for a few weeks it was really itchy, but apparently that is just your body's response to having a foreign object implanted in it.  Now I don't even notice it at all.  The only time it bothers me is if someone hugs me too hard (people don't even know that is it there).  I have had no problems with infections and just finished chemo #15!  I know it is a constant reminder of having cancer (like we need anymore reminders) but it really is convenient.  Best of luck. Lisa
Posts.Title: I finally HAVE to get a port...whaaaaa tooyoungtohavebc dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 11:55PM Lisa73 wrote: Melanie: Sorry about your news.  I am having my 15th dose of Taxotere today.  I have had it every 3 weeks since last March.  I have found the side effects to be tolerable, and I think each person has a unique response.  My hair didn't start thinning until after the second dose, and I didn't lose it completely until after the third dose.  I haven't had any problems with my nails.  After the first dose I did feel somewhat naseous, but I didn't vomit.  My experience is that I feel full of energy for the first 3 days (from the steroids) and then I crash on the fourth day.  My energy picks back up after that and I have two weeks where I feel fine.  I also find I have a "yucky" taste in my mouth on days 5 and 6 after chemo, but that is really it for side effects.  Overall, it has greatly improved my quality of life as I could barely walk before starting chemo due to the extensive bone mets.  My cancer is now considered stable! Enjoy the wedding and Disneyland and I am hoping you have very few side effects from Taxotere.  Lisa
Posts.Title: I've got crappy news as well Melanie36 Melanie36

Posts.Content: May 1, 2010 07:36PM Lisa73 wrote: Jackie - Thanks for the info on your situation, and so glad to hear you finally found someone with a solution for you.  I am definitely going to ask my oncologist when I see her at my next visit about getting a second opinion.  I too wondered if the orthopedic surgeon dismissed the idea of surgery because of my Stage IV diagnosis.  skidoo33 - I am googling hemiarthoplasty as soon as I log off of here.  Thanks for the info, it is much appreciated :) Lisa
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: Lisa73 wrote: I can't believe last week at this time I was fretting about the possiblity of having surgery to repair a fracture in my femur.  Today I saw an orthopedic surgeon and he said that surgery isn't an option.  My oncologist had explained to me that I had a small peice of bone sticking into a muscle, and this was the reason for the swelling in my leg, tight muscles and difficulty walking.  In reality, what I have is called an "avulsion fracture of the great trochanter" which basically means that tendons and ligaments have torn away a piece of bone at the top of my femur (the top of the femur is covered in bone mets).  Surgery is not generally an option.  The surgeon suggested I continue physio to help stretch and strengthen the muscle and lymphatic massage to help with the swelling.  My husband asked him what the chances were of this healing naturally, and responed "medium" but he didn't look that hopeful.  I would be interested to hear of anyone else with bone mets who had an avulsion fracture.  I am trying to stay postive, but this crazy disease has already taken so much from me.  I guess hour long walks are now a thing of the past too.  Longing for the beauty of an ordinary day, free of cancer and all the limitations it brings to life. Dx 2/24/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: May 2, 2010 07:35PM Lisa73 wrote: Nicki- So sorry to hear about your possible fracture.  I hear you about being sick and tired of dealing with this disease.  The last year has just been one thing after another.  I hope you get an answer to your problem too - good luck with your surgery if you decide to go ahead with it.  Wishing you the best. Lisa
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:04AM Lisa73 wrote: Terry3N - I have thought of asking for a second opinion - I will discuss it with my onc when I see her again.  I have taken Aredia for the last year, but like czsteve, I thought it was supposed to build my bones up, not break them down, so I would be interested in any info you have on that.  I don't need a total hip replacement (yet!) - the lesions and the avulsion fracture are on the top of the femur.  In fact, the orthopedic surgeon said that I was lucky they weren't in the hip socket or further down the femur where they could cause a more serious fracture (says the guy who can walk properly :)). Shiny - Thanks for the hug:) czsteve - Hope you have a speedy recovery!  Praying for you too. Lisa
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2010 08:30AM Lisa73 wrote: Nanalinda- I have had radiation to the area two times - one big shot of radiation in April 09 and then 5 smaller doses over 5 days in Dec 09.  The first radiation in April 09 gave me tonnes of relief.  But then last fall I started having difficulty walking and more pain in that area, so they did more radiation.  In retrospect, I think it was the fracture causing the pain, as the second time I had the radiation didn't give me that much pain relief.  And I have heard that radiation can weaken the bones and lead to fractures, so it seems to me it is all a vicious circle! Sorry to hear about the bone mets in your spine.  I have them there too, but no problems have developed as of yet.  Twelve months of Taxotere helped beat them down a little bit:) Lisa
Posts.Title: No bone mets surgery for me:( Lisa73 palaminoridesagain

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 09:06AM Lisa73 wrote: Thank you ladies for your input.  I am relieved to know that others have gone through orthopedic surgery with success - I had no idea it was even a possibility.  Your right, 33skidoo, it does seem like a "no-brainer" to have the surgery done :)  But, my oncologist has been so opposed to my having surgery to have my breast removed, that it surprised when she said I might be able to have surgery to repair a bone fracture in my leg.  Of course she said there are no guarantees, but I see the orthopedic surgeon next Thursday and hopefully he will tell me he can fix me up!

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2010 03:46PM Lisa73 wrote: I saw this article on the weekend too!  How exciting.  And it seems it is already used for some cancers such as prostate cancer.  It will be interesting to see what the clinical trials show.  Definitely talking to my oncologist about this. Lisa

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2010 09:17PM Lisa73 wrote: Janis, I am still on the fence about the breast removal.  When I was first diagnosed my bone mets were so bad I could barely walk, so the first goal was chemo to knock the cancer on its butt.  I was surprised at first when my oncologist said no to surgery to remove the breast, and was really upset about it for months.  Once I was stable, she said she would refer me to a surgeon if I wanted, but now I am not sure.  I have read lots of articles on both sides of the issue and it is hard to make a decision.  But I am not as freaked out about it as I was at first, especially after reading about so many women on this board who have not had their breast removed either.

Posts.Content: Lisa73 wrote: Hi, my name is Lisa and I am relatively new to these boards - I only discovered this website back in January but have already learned so much from reading the posts on this forum. Here is my story in brief: I was diagnosed 14 months ago at age 36 and started at Stage IV (bones and liver).  I have done 15 doses of Taxotere over the last 12 months and my cancer is stable so I am currently on Tamoxifen.  I have had difficulty walking on my right side and the right hip area has been swollen for months.  A recent MRI (April 8) revealed that a tiny portion of my bone has splintered away and is sticking into the muscle - so that has what has been giving me so much difficulty walking.  My oncologist has referred me to an orthopedic surgeon at Sunnybrook (Toronto).  She said he may or may not be able to help me. So my question is, has anyone had orthopedic surgery for bone mets?  Was it successful?  I am kind of worried about going through surgery, but would give anything to be able to walk properly again.  If anyone had any experiences to share or advice to give, it would be greatly appreciated.  Lisa Dx 2/24/2009, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery for bone mets problem? Lisa73 33skidoo
